title: Acute Confusion Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing acute confusion (delirium), focusing on identifying causes, maintaining safety, improving cognition, and preventing complications in patients experiencing rapid onset of altered mental status.

assessments.title: Mental Status Assessment
points: Assess level of consciousness using standardized tool (Glasgow Coma Scale, AVPU)
Evaluate orientation to person, place, time, and situation
Assess attention span and concentration using validated tools (CAM, NEECHAM)
Evaluate for fluctuations in mental status throughout the day
Assess memory (immediate, recent, remote)
Evaluate thought processes and content for disorganization or hallucinations
Assess sleep-wake cycle disruption
assessments.description: Comprehensive mental status assessment helps identify the presence, severity, and fluctuations of acute confusion, guiding appropriate interventions

assessments.title: Etiological Assessment
points: Review medication regimen for potential contributors (anticholinergics, sedatives, opioids)
Assess for signs of infection (fever, elevated WBC, localized symptoms)
Evaluate for metabolic disturbances (electrolyte imbalances, hypoglycemia, hypoxia)
Assess for substance withdrawal (alcohol, benzodiazepines)
Evaluate for sensory deficits (vision, hearing)
Assess for pain using appropriate scale
Review for recent surgical procedures or trauma
assessments.description: Etiological assessment helps identify potentially reversible causes of acute confusion that require specific interventions

assessments.title: Behavioral Assessment
points: Assess for psychomotor agitation or retardation
Evaluate for presence of hallucinations or delusions
Assess for inappropriate behavior or emotional responses
Evaluate for day-night reversal
Assess for combative or aggressive behavior
Evaluate for safety risks (falls, self-harm, pulling at tubes/lines)
Assess impact of behaviors on care delivery
assessments.description: Behavioral assessment helps identify safety concerns and guides appropriate interventions to manage behavioral manifestations of acute confusion

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Acute Confusion related to multiple etiologies as evidenced by fluctuating level of consciousness, disorientation, and perceptual disturbances
definingCharacteristics: Disorientation to time, place, person, or situation

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Injury related to altered cognitive functioning and psychomotor agitation
relatedFactors: Lack of awareness of environmental hazards
definingCharacteristics: Pulling at tubes, lines, or restraints
Attempting to get out of bed unsafely

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved cognitive status with decreased confusion
indicators: Improved orientation to person, place, time, and situation
Decreased episodes of agitation and restlessness
Improved ability to follow simple commands

goals.statement: Patient will remain free from injury during episodes of confusion

interventions.title: Delirium Management
actions: Identify and treat underlying causes in collaboration with healthcare team
Implement frequent orientation techniques (clock, calendar, familiar objects)
Maintain consistent caregivers when possible
Establish predictable routines and schedules
Provide appropriate sensory aids (glasses, hearing aids)
Minimize environmental stimuli, especially at night
Promote normal sleep-wake cycle (natural light during day, darkness at night)
Use simple, clear communication with short sentences
rationales: Addressing underlying causes is essential for resolving delirium
Orientation cues help reduce confusion and improve awareness
Consistency reduces anxiety and promotes recognition
Predictable routines increase sense of security and reduce confusion
Sensory aids improve environmental interpretation and reduce misperceptions
Reduced stimuli prevents sensory overload and agitation
Normal sleep-wake cycle improves cognitive function
Simple communication improves comprehension during cognitive impairment
specialConsiderations: Avoid physical restraints when possible as they may worsen confusion and agitation
Consider 1:1 observation for severely agitated patients
Minimize use of sedating medications which may worsen confusion

interventions.title: Reality Orientation
actions: Reorient to person, place, time, and situation frequently
Address patient by preferred name
Introduce self with each interaction
Explain all procedures and activities before initiating
Place orientation board with day, date, location in patient's view
Encourage family to bring familiar objects from home
Involve family in orientation activities
Correct misperceptions gently without confrontation
rationales: Frequent reorientation helps maintain awareness of reality
Using preferred name promotes recognition and dignity
Self-introduction provides consistent orientation cue
Explanations reduce fear and confusion about activities
Visual cues reinforce orientation information
Familiar objects provide comfort and recognition
Family involvement provides reassurance and familiar references
Non-confrontational approach prevents increased agitation
interventions.frequency: Every 1-2 hours and with each interaction

interventions.title: Environmental Management: Safety
actions: Implement fall precautions according to facility protocol
Place call light within reach and demonstrate use
Ensure adequate lighting with night light for evening hours
Remove unnecessary equipment from room
Secure tubes, lines, and catheters appropriately
Consider bed/chair alarm for patients at high risk for getting up unassisted
Provide supervision during ambulation
Maintain bed in lowest position with brakes locked
rationales: Fall precautions reduce risk of injury during confusion
Accessible call light enables patient to request assistance
Appropriate lighting reduces misperceptions and shadows
Uncluttered environment reduces stimuli and hazards
Secured devices prevent accidental dislodgement
Alarms alert staff to unauthorized movement
Supervision prevents falls during ambulation
Low bed position minimizes injury risk if fall occurs

expectedOutcomes: Improved orientation to person, place, time, and situation
Decreased episodes of agitation and restlessness
evaluationMethods: Mental status assessment using standardized tools (CAM, NEECHAM)
Staff and family reports of interactions

evaluations.statement: Has patient remained free from injury?
expectedOutcomes: Decreased need for restraints or constant observation
evaluationMethods: Observation of response to safety interventions
Documentation of restraint use if applicable

title: Chronic Confusion Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing chronic confusion associated with dementia and other neurocognitive disorders, focusing on maintaining function, promoting safety, supporting communication, and enhancing quality of life for patients with progressive cognitive decline.

assessments.title: Cognitive Assessment
points: Assess cognitive function using standardized tools (MMSE, MoCA, SLUMS)
Evaluate orientation to person, place, time, and situation
Assess memory (immediate, recent, remote)
Evaluate executive function (planning, problem-solving, judgment)
Assess language abilities (comprehension, expression, naming)
Evaluate visuospatial abilities
Document baseline cognitive status and monitor for changes
assessments.description: Comprehensive cognitive assessment helps establish baseline function, identify specific deficits, and guide appropriate interventions for chronic confusion

assessments.title: Functional Assessment
points: Assess ability to perform basic ADLs (bathing, dressing, toileting, feeding)
Evaluate ability to perform IADLs (medication management, finances, transportation)
Assess mobility and fall risk
Evaluate safety awareness and judgment
Assess ability to follow simple and multi-step commands
Evaluate need for assistive devices or environmental modifications
Assess caregiver support and involvement
assessments.description: Functional assessment helps identify areas requiring assistance, guide care planning, and maximize independence while ensuring safety

assessments.title: Behavioral Assessment
points: Assess for presence of behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD)
Evaluate for agitation, aggression, or combativeness
Assess for wandering behaviors and elopement risk
Evaluate for anxiety, depression, or apathy
Assess for hallucinations or delusions
Evaluate sleep disturbances
Identify triggers for behavioral symptoms
assessments.description: Behavioral assessment helps identify specific behavioral challenges requiring intervention and potential triggers that can be modified or avoided

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Chronic Confusion related to neurocognitive disorders as evidenced by progressive cognitive decline, disorientation, and impaired memory
Self-Care Deficit related to cognitive impairment as evidenced by inability to independently perform activities of daily living
definingCharacteristics: Impaired ability to perform toileting activities

goals.statement: Patient will maintain optimal cognitive function within limitations of condition
indicators: Engages in familiar and meaningful activities

goals.statement: Patient will remain safe and free from injury related to cognitive impairment
indicators: Maintains safe environment with appropriate supervision
Accepts assistance with activities requiring judgment
Responds to redirection when engaging in unsafe behaviors
Uses assistive devices appropriately with cueing

goals.statement: Caregiver will demonstrate effective management strategies for chronic confusion
indicators: Implements environmental modifications to enhance function
Demonstrates effective responses to behavioral symptoms
Provides appropriate level of assistance with ADLs
Identifies and utilizes available resources and support

interventions.title: Reality Orientation
actions: Provide orientation information in a matter-of-fact, non-confrontational manner
Use orientation aids (clocks, calendars, signs, labels)
Maintain consistent daily routines and schedules
Address patient by preferred name
Introduce self and explain purpose with each interaction
Provide environmental cues for time of day and activities
Avoid arguing or correcting when patient is confused about reality
rationales: Gentle orientation helps maintain connection to reality without causing distress
Visual cues reinforce orientation information
Consistency reduces confusion and provides security
Using preferred name maintains dignity and recognition
Introduction provides consistent orientation cue
Environmental cues support temporal awareness
Avoiding confrontation prevents agitation and preserves dignity
specialConsiderations: Transition to validation therapy when reality orientation causes distress
Adapt approach based on stage of dementia and individual response
Consider cultural factors that influence perception of time and place

interventions.title: Dementia Management
actions: Implement person-centered care approach
Create a calm, structured environment with familiar objects
Reduce environmental stimuli that may cause agitation
Provide cognitive stimulation at appropriate level (reminiscence, music therapy)
Use simple, one-step directions and allow time for processing
Maintain consistent caregivers when possible
Implement behavioral management strategies for BPSD
Provide support and education to family/caregivers
rationales: Person-centered care honors individuality and preferences
Familiar environment reduces confusion and provides comfort
Reduced stimuli prevents overload and agitation
Appropriate stimulation maintains cognitive function
Simple directions accommodate processing deficits
Consistency improves recognition and reduces anxiety
Behavioral strategies reduce need for pharmacological interventions
Caregiver support improves care continuity and reduces burden
specialConsiderations: Adapt interventions to stage of dementia and changing abilities
Consider impact of physical illness on cognitive function
Balance safety needs with autonomy and dignity

interventions.title: Environmental Management: Safety
actions: Implement fall prevention strategies
Secure potentially dangerous items (medications, cleaning supplies)
Provide supervision during activities requiring judgment
Use door alarms or monitoring systems for wandering risk
Ensure adequate lighting to reduce misperceptions
Remove unnecessary clutter and obstacles
Consider use of identification bracelet or GPS device
Evaluate need for assistive devices and ensure proper use
rationales: Fall prevention reduces injury risk
Securing hazardous items prevents accidental ingestion or misuse
Supervision compensates for impaired judgment
Monitoring systems alert to potential elopement
Adequate lighting reduces misperceptions and shadows
Uncluttered environment reduces confusion and hazards
Identification aids assist in returning patient if lost
Appropriate assistive devices support function and safety

evaluations.statement: Is patient maintaining optimal cognitive function within limitations?
expectedOutcomes: Participates in cognitive activities at level of ability
Shows stable or slowed rate of cognitive decline
evaluationMethods: Periodic cognitive assessment using standardized tools
Observation of daily function and activities
Staff and caregiver reports of interactions

evaluations.statement: Has patient remained safe despite cognitive impairment?
expectedOutcomes: No incidents of wandering or elopement
Appropriate use of assistive devices with cueing
Accepts assistance with activities requiring judgment
evaluationMethods: Observation of behavior and response to safety interventions

evaluations.statement: Does caregiver demonstrate effective management strategies?
expectedOutcomes: Demonstrates effective responses to behavioral symptoms

title: Impaired Verbal Communication Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing impaired verbal communication, focusing on assessment of specific deficits, implementation of alternative communication methods, and support for patients experiencing communication difficulties due to neurological conditions such as stroke, traumatic brain injury, or progressive neurological diseases.

assessments.title: Communication Assessment
points: Assess type and severity of communication impairment (expressive, receptive, global aphasia, dysarthria, apraxia)
Evaluate comprehension of verbal and written language
Assess ability to express needs verbally, in writing, or through gestures
Evaluate reading and writing abilities
Assess speech characteristics (articulation, fluency, volume, rate)
Evaluate for presence of word-finding difficulties
Assess ability to follow commands of varying complexity
assessments.description: Comprehensive communication assessment helps identify specific deficits and preserved abilities to guide appropriate interventions and communication strategies

assessments.title: Neurological Assessment
points: Evaluate for underlying neurological conditions (stroke, TBI, neurodegenerative disease)
Assess cranial nerve function related to speech (V, VII, IX, X, XII)
Evaluate motor function of speech-related structures (lips, tongue, soft palate)
Assess for presence of right or left-sided weakness or paralysis
Evaluate swallowing function and coordination
Assess for changes in level of consciousness or cognition
Document location and extent of neurological lesions if known
assessments.description: Neurological assessment helps identify the underlying cause and specific deficits contributing to communication impairment

assessments.title: Psychosocial Assessment
points: Assess emotional response to communication impairment
Evaluate for signs of frustration, anxiety, or depression
Assess impact on social interactions and relationships
Evaluate coping strategies and adaptation to communication changes
Assess family/caregiver understanding and response to communication impairment
Evaluate previous communication style and preferences
Assess cultural and language factors affecting communication
assessments.description: Psychosocial assessment helps identify emotional impact and support needs related to communication impairment

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Impaired Verbal Communication related to neurological impairment as evidenced by inability to speak, difficulty forming words, and inability to name objects
Risk for Situational Low Self-Esteem related to functional impairment in communication

goals.statement: Patient will establish effective means of communication using available abilities and alternative methods
indicators: Communicates basic needs and wants consistently
Demonstrates improved verbal expression if potential exists
Indicates understanding of communication from others

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate reduced frustration related to communication difficulties
indicators: Uses effective coping strategies when communication is difficult
Shows decreased signs of frustration or agitation
Continues to attempt communication despite difficulties

goals.statement: Caregivers will demonstrate effective communication strategies with patient
indicators: Provides adequate time for patient response
Demonstrates use of alternative communication methods

interventions.title: Communication Enhancement
actions: Establish consistent method for indicating yes/no responses
Implement alternative communication methods (picture boards, letter boards, communication apps)
Provide writing materials if writing ability is preserved
Use simple, direct sentences and ask one question at a time
Allow sufficient time for patient to process information and respond
Validate successful communication attempts
Minimize environmental distractions during communication
Collaborate with speech-language pathologist for specialized interventions
rationales: Consistent yes/no method provides foundation for basic communication
Alternative methods bypass verbal impairments
Writing offers alternative expression channel if preserved
Simple language reduces cognitive processing demands
Processing time accommodates neurological deficits
Validation reinforces successful strategies
Reduced distractions improve focus on communication
Speech therapy provides specialized expertise for communication rehabilitation
specialConsiderations: Adapt methods based on type and severity of communication impairment
Consider cultural and language factors in communication approach
Adjust strategies as communication abilities change

interventions.title: Active Listening
actions: Maintain eye contact and attentive body language
Focus completely on communication attempt without interrupting
Watch for nonverbal cues and gestures
Verify understanding by restating or clarifying
Acknowledge communication attempts even when unsuccessful
Avoid completing sentences or words unless requested
Demonstrate patience during communication attempts
Use touch appropriately to convey attention and support
rationales: Attentive nonverbals demonstrate interest and engagement
Uninterrupted attention allows patient to complete thoughts
Nonverbal cues provide additional communication information
Verification confirms accurate understanding
Acknowledgment encourages continued communication efforts
Avoiding completion respects autonomy and self-expression
Patience reduces anxiety and pressure during communication
Appropriate touch provides reassurance and connection

interventions.title: Emotional Support
actions: Acknowledge frustration related to communication difficulties
Provide reassurance and encouragement during communication attempts
Create opportunities for successful communication experiences
Encourage expression of feelings about communication changes
Maintain dignity and respect during all interactions
Involve in decision-making to extent possible
Connect with support groups or others with similar conditions
Provide information about communication disorder and recovery process
rationales: Acknowledgment validates emotional experience
Encouragement maintains motivation for communication
Success experiences build confidence and reduce helplessness
Emotional expression promotes adjustment and coping
Respect preserves self-esteem despite communication limitations
Decision involvement maintains autonomy and control
Peer support reduces isolation and provides hope
Information promotes understanding and realistic expectations

evaluations.statement: Has patient established effective means of communication?
expectedOutcomes: Consistently communicates basic needs and wants
Shows improvement in verbal expression if potential exists
Demonstrates understanding of communication from others
Participates in social interactions despite limitations

evaluations.statement: Has patient demonstrated reduced frustration with communication?
expectedOutcomes: Uses effective coping strategies when communication is difficult

Continues to attempt communication despite difficulties
Participates willingly in communication enhancement activities

evaluations.statement: Do caregivers demonstrate effective communication strategies?
expectedOutcomes: Provide adequate time for patient response
Demonstrate use of alternative communication methods
Express confidence in ability to communicate with patient

title: Disturbed Sensory Perception Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing disturbed sensory perception, focusing on assessment of specific sensory deficits, implementation of compensatory strategies, and prevention of complications in patients experiencing alterations in sensory perception due to neurological conditions such as stroke, traumatic brain injury, or peripheral neuropathy.

assessments.title: Sensory Perception Assessment
points: Assess specific sensory modalities affected (visual, auditory, tactile, gustatory, olfactory, kinesthetic)
Evaluate visual fields, acuity, and perception
Assess hearing acuity and auditory processing
Evaluate tactile sensation (light touch, pressure, temperature, pain)
Assess proprioception and kinesthetic awareness
Evaluate for presence of unilateral neglect or inattention
Assess for hallucinations or illusions
assessments.description: Comprehensive sensory assessment helps identify specific deficits and preserved abilities to guide appropriate interventions and safety measures

assessments.title: Neurological Assessment
points: Evaluate for underlying neurological conditions (stroke, TBI, neuropathy)
Assess cranial nerve function related to sensory perception (I, II, V, VII, VIII)
Evaluate for cortical or subcortical lesions affecting perception
Assess for peripheral nerve damage or neuropathy
Evaluate for changes in level of consciousness or cognition
Assess for hemianopsia or visual field cuts
Document location and extent of neurological lesions if known
assessments.description: Neurological assessment helps identify the underlying cause and specific deficits contributing to sensory perception disturbances

assessments.title: Functional Impact Assessment
points: Assess impact of sensory deficits on mobility and fall risk
Evaluate effect on activities of daily living
Assess ability to identify environmental hazards
Evaluate impact on spatial orientation and navigation
Assess effect on communication (reading, facial expression recognition)
Evaluate awareness and insight into sensory deficits
Assess compensatory strategies currently used
assessments.description: Functional assessment helps identify safety concerns and practical implications of sensory deficits requiring intervention

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Disturbed Sensory Perception related to neurological impairment as evidenced by change in sensory acuity and altered perception of stimuli
definingCharacteristics: Change in usual response to stimuli
Reported or measured change in sensory acuity

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Injury related to sensory perceptual alterations
relatedFactors: Lack of awareness of environmental hazards
definingCharacteristics: Bumping into objects on affected side

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate compensatory strategies to manage sensory deficits safely
indicators: Uses scanning techniques to compensate for visual field deficits
Positions self to maximize use of intact sensory abilities
Modifies environment to accommodate sensory deficits

goals.statement: Patient will remain free from injury related to sensory perceptual alterations
Patient will demonstrate improved functional independence despite sensory deficits

interventions.title: Sensory Deficit Management
actions: Approach patient from unaffected side
Teach visual scanning techniques for visual field deficits
Position personal items within visual field or reach
Provide sensory aids (glasses, hearing aids, magnifiers)
Implement sensory stimulation to affected areas as appropriate
Teach patient to visually monitor affected limbs during movement
Provide consistent environmental arrangement
Collaborate with occupational and physical therapy for specialized interventions
rationales: Approaching from unaffected side ensures patient awareness of presence
Scanning techniques compensate for visual field deficits
Appropriate positioning ensures access to needed items
Sensory aids maximize remaining sensory function
Stimulation may improve sensory awareness and prevent neglect
Visual monitoring compensates for proprioceptive deficits
Consistency reduces confusion and navigation challenges
Therapy provides specialized expertise for sensory rehabilitation
specialConsiderations: Adapt interventions based on type and severity of sensory deficit
Consider potential for sensory overload in some patients
Adjust strategies as sensory function changes

interventions.title: Environmental Management: Safety
actions: Implement fall prevention strategies
Remove obstacles from pathways, especially on affected side
Ensure adequate lighting without glare
Use contrasting colors to highlight important objects
Apply colored tape to edges of steps or thresholds
Keep call light within reach on unaffected side
Orient to environment with each room change
Provide supervision during mobility until safety demonstrated
rationales: Fall prevention reduces injury risk
Clear pathways prevent collisions and falls
Appropriate lighting improves visual perception
Contrast enhances visual identification of objects
Visual cues highlight potential hazards
Accessible call light ensures ability to request assistance
Reorientation accommodates spatial perception difficulties
Supervision ensures safety until compensatory skills developed

interventions.title: Unilateral Neglect Management
actions: Position self and important items in patient's attended visual field
Gradually introduce activities that cross midline
Use verbal and tactile cues to draw attention to neglected side
Teach visual scanning from neglected to attended side
Place bright markers on neglected side of reading material
Encourage limb activation on neglected side
Implement mirror therapy if appropriate
Provide feedback about neglected body parts and space
rationales: Positioning in attended field ensures awareness
Midline-crossing activities improve integration of neglected space
Cues redirect attention to neglected areas
Systematic scanning improves awareness of entire visual field
Visual markers prompt attention to neglected text
Active movement improves body awareness and attention
Mirror therapy improves awareness of affected limb
Feedback increases consciousness of neglect

evaluations.statement: Is patient using compensatory strategies effectively?
expectedOutcomes: Consistently uses scanning techniques for visual deficits
Positions self to maximize sensory input
Modifies activities to accommodate sensory deficits
Shows improved attention to neglected side if applicable

Has functional independence improved despite sensory deficits?
